docs.snippet: Political killings and human rights violations increased significantly in Guatemala last year, according to figures provided by the American Embassy here.    Nonetheless, the embassy has cited an improving political climate in arguing that ''overa...
docs.lead_paragraph: Political killings and human rights violations increased significantly in Guatemala last year, according to figures provided by the American Embassy here. Nonetheless, the embassy has cited an improving political climate in arguing that ''overall human rights conditions'' have improved in Guatemala, an assessment that is shared by the leaders of most political parties here. Political debate has increased and presidential elections have been scheduled. According to the embassy's latest human rights report, covering 1984, there were 950 politically motivated disappearances and killings of civilians here last year. Of that total, 425 were disappearances and 525 were killings.

headline.main: GUATEMALA, AWAITING VOTE, LEARNS KILLINGS RISE

docs.snippet: DREAMS THAT MONEY CAN BUY. The    Tragic Life of Libby Holman. By Jon   Bradshaw. 431 pages. Illustrated. William Morrow & Company. $17.95.  Though she was already famous for her dark, smoky-voiced renditions of ''Body and Soul'' and ''Moanin' Low...
docs.lead_paragraph: DREAMS THAT MONEY CAN BUY. The Tragic Life of Libby Holman. By Jon Bradshaw. 431 pages. Illustrated. William Morrow & Company. $17.95. Though she was already famous for her dark, smoky-voiced renditions of ''Body and Soul'' and ''Moanin' Low'' and for her appearances on stage in ''The Little Show'' and ''Three's a Crowd,'' the torch singer Libby Holman would go on to win a different kind of celebrity in 1932, when she was accused of murdering her husband, the flamboyant tobacco heir Zachary Smith Reynolds. The charges were later dropped, but the case became something of a national sensation - it even inspired an M-G-M movie starring Jean Harlow - and would continue to cast shadows over the rest of the singer's life. She committed suicide in 1971.

headline.main: Books of The Times;   A TORCH-SONG LIFE

docs.snippet: The stock of the American Natural Resources Company surged to a 52- week high in heavy trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange as company officials indicated that they would fight an expected acquisition attempt.     The stock jumped by 4...
docs.lead_paragraph: The stock of the American Natural Resources Company surged to a 52- week high in heavy trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange as company officials indicated that they would fight an expected acquisition attempt. The stock jumped by 4 1/8, to 53 3/4, following reports in The Wall Street Journal that the Coastal Corporation, the Houston-based oil and gas company, would soon make a bid for American Natural Resources, also an oil and gas concern. American Natural Resources, which is based in Detroit, said on Thursday that it was establishing a publicly traded limited partnership for its oil and gas reserves, a move several analysts said was taken to make a takeover more difficult.

docs.snippet: BOTH Charles N. Blakemore and James Killough have fled top executive positions with major establishment advertising agencies in order to escape ''the process.''   And that, explained Mr. Blakemore, the agency business's most successful native of B...
docs.lead_paragraph: BOTH Charles N. Blakemore and James Killough have fled top executive positions with major establishment advertising agencies in order to escape ''the process.'' And that, explained Mr. Blakemore, the agency business's most successful native of Bedford, Iowa, is short for ''when the process of managing the business becomes more important than delivering the product.'' They don't need much of the process these days since there is just the two of them and a secretary under the partnership banner of Blakemore & Killough ensconced in some extra footage in the offices of the SFM Media Corporation. ''I want to spend the rest of my life with Charlie,'' said the 49-year-old Mr. Killough in jocular fashion.

docs.snippet: ON March 11, Columbia Records will release ''We Are the World,'' a new song written by Lionel Richie and Michael Jackson and performed by a chorus of 45 pop stars calling themselves USA for Africa (United Support of Artists for Africa). Roughly 90...
docs.lead_paragraph: ON March 11, Columbia Records will release ''We Are the World,'' a new song written by Lionel Richie and Michael Jackson and performed by a chorus of 45 pop stars calling themselves USA for Africa (United Support of Artists for Africa). Roughly 90 percent of the proceeds from the single and an album to be released April 1, as well as a full- length video and related merchandizing, will be donated to African famine relief. Another 10 percent will go to fight homelessness and malnutrition in the United States. ''We Are the World'' is an American response to ''Do They Know It's Christmas?,'' the single that was recorded late last year in London by Band Aid, a group of British rock stars. The record became the most successful single in British history, selling 3.5 million copies in Britain and 2.5 million in the United States and raising $9.2 million.

docs.snippet: Linwood G. Dunn, longtime head of photographic effects for RKO, will receive the Gordon E. Sawyer Award for his contributions to movie technology at the Oscar ceremony on March 25, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences announced last wee...
docs.lead_paragraph: Linwood G. Dunn, longtime head of photographic effects for RKO, will receive the Gordon E. Sawyer Award for his contributions to movie technology at the Oscar ceremony on March 25, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences announced last week. Mr. Dunn, whose credits include ''King Kong,'' ''Citizen Kane'' and ''West Side Story,'' is the fourth recipient of the award that was established to recognize outstanding contributions toward the advancement of the sciences or technology of the motion picture.

docs.snippet: IF Jay Howell were still a member of the Yankees' pitching staff, he would be in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., working himself into shape for his role as the No. 2 relief pitcher, the set- up man for Dave Righetti. The Yankees, though, traded Howell to O...
docs.lead_paragraph: IF Jay Howell were still a member of the Yankees' pitching staff, he would be in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., working himself into shape for his role as the No. 2 relief pitcher, the set- up man for Dave Righetti. The Yankees, though, traded Howell to Oakland in December, and now he must wait until Thursday to begin spring training in Phoenix in his new role as the No. 1 relief pitcher for the A's. ''I can't wait to show them what they got,'' Howell said, awaiting the biggest opportunity of his 10-year career. ''All winter, I've read how great it is that the Yankees got Rickey Henderson. I want to show the A's they got something good in the trade, too.'' The acquisition of Howell, along with four other players, in the Henderson trade enabled the A's to send Bill Caudill, their bullpen stopper, to Toronto. Caudill registered 36 saves for the team that once upon a time was accustomed to Rollie Fingers' saving everything in sight. Is Howell ready to inherit that legacy as the No. 1 reliever?

headline.main: After Trade by Yanks to A's, Howell Has His Big Chance

docs.snippet: No basic plot is more enduring in the pop marketplace than the one tracing a steady and juicily melodramatic progression from rags to riches. It has worked deliciously in old movies like ''Mrs. Parkington'' and ''The Valley of Decision.'' It has b...
docs.lead_paragraph: No basic plot is more enduring in the pop marketplace than the one tracing a steady and juicily melodramatic progression from rags to riches. It has worked deliciously in old movies like ''Mrs. Parkington'' and ''The Valley of Decision.'' It has been milked shamelessly in countless radio and TV soap operas doing variations on women from obscure mining towns possibly finding happiness with worldly aristocrats. It continues to be a staple of TV mini-series. More recent examples include ''A Woman of Substance'' and ''Ellis Island.'' And tonight at 9 on NBC, it is trotted out once again in the three-part ''Evergreen.'' The second and third episodes will be broadcast tomorrow and Tuesday, also at 9 P.M.

docs.snippet: WILLIAM HART contributes to The New York Times from Santa Fe.         By WILLIAM HART    Over 100 years ago, visitors to the remote mountain country near Ruidoso. N.M., came armed. Its deep stillness was shattered by gunfire as the newly ascendant...
docs.lead_paragraph: WILLIAM HART contributes to The New York Times from Santa Fe. By WILLIAM HART Over 100 years ago, visitors to the remote mountain country near Ruidoso. N.M., came armed. Its deep stillness was shattered by gunfire as the newly ascendant U.S. cavalry hunted down the last Mescalero Apaches, who had, until then, refused to exchange raiding for reservation life. Superior in both numbers and weapons, the cavalry prevailed. The Mescaleros, once - with their brother Apaches - the dominant tribe of the Southwestern plains, were permanently settled on their reservation, as subjects of a distant government, And the Mescaleros survived, as has the fierce beauty of their 460,000- acre tribal land, centered on 12,000- foot Sierra Blanca, the highest peak in the Sacramento range. These mountains were sacred to the Indians well before New Spain became New Mexico.
